For a monoid $M$ and elements $a_{1}, \ldots, a_{n} \in M$, the product is defined as $\prod_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} := a_{1} \cdot \ldots \cdot a_{n}$. A special bracketing on the right-hand side is not necessary due to the associative nature of the law of composition.
A map is a relationship between two sets that associates every element in one set(domain) to exactly one element in another set (codomain).
Does the concept of a/an Product Notation in Monoids need to be defined for a definition of a/an Map/Function to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of a map or function is foundational in mathematics and is defined independently of the structure of the elements in the domain or codomain. A map simply requires each element of the domain to be associated with exactly one element in the codomain, without any additional structure on these sets. 

On the other hand, the concept of product notation in monoids pertains specifically to the algebraic structure of monoids, where elements can be combined using an associative binary operation. This concept is used to define the product of multiple elements in a monoid but does not influence the basic definition of a map or function. 

Therefore, the definition and understanding of a map or function do not depend on the concept of product notation in monoids. The two concepts operate independently in their respective mathematical contexts.
